WRITING.TITLE: Donald Trump has "made racism great again"
Back up generator?
WRITING.TEXT:
I live in the UK and I'm moving onto a canal boat in the next few months. I'm in the process of designing an off grid solar system for it at the moment. I've noticed that a lot of inverters have an auto start system for back up generators when the battery levels get too low.
As the weather in the UK doesn't tend to be too great in the winter I'm probably going to need a back up generator sometimes but I'm having trouble finding a small generator which would be compatible with this auto-start feature. I'm only ever going to need between 1-2kw but all the generators I can find in this range are recoil start. Can anyone recommend a back up generator with auto start functionality in this power range?
what kind of format do you expect for hard copies? Individual portfolio pages or a bound document? What sort of size?

of the people in the year above me at my school that graduated last July (over 100) only a handful have managed to find placements. Also the job sites pretty consistently have at least twice as many part 2 vacancies whenever I look at them, regardless of the time of year.
Obviously I would prefer to work in an architecture practice, I'm just trying to be realistic and prepare for the worst eventuality so that I can move onto my part 2 as quickly as possible.

according to the website: " 'Qualified professional' will be an architect registered in the territory where the experience is being undertaken, or a chartered or similarly qualified member of an appropriate professional body" 12 months do have to be under the supervision of an architect but you can also do 12 months under another qualified professional in the construction industry if it proves difficult finding a placement with an architect. Thinking about it more now labouring wouldnt count as there wouldn't be a chartered professional that could supervise you but other suggestions in this thread could work.

I want to switch schools for my part 2 for several reasons. All the schools I want to switch to are pretty insistent about part 1 experience. I'm just trying to be realistic and look for a backup plan because the part 1 vacancies are consistently sparse. There's usually plenty of people looking for part 2's but the part 1 vacancies are much harder to come by. My dad is a retired civil engineer though so maybe some of his old contacts might be able to help find something more fitting than general labouring.

WRITING.TITLE: UK Architects - Does anyone know if working on a building site as a labourer can count towards PEDR?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm about to finish my part 1 and thinking of this as a possible backup while I'm looking for a part 1 placement. The PEDR website states "experience within the construction industry under the supervision of a qualified professional within the relevant field". Would working as a labourer count under this definition?

The thing I like about him is as soon as the facts were pointed out he put his hands up and admitted he was wrong then praised the caller for the quality of his contribution. Not many media figures would do that nowadays.

WRITING.TEXT:
the Speaker has only said that he won't invite Trump to address Westminster Hall because that's the venue he has power over.
The only people in recent memory that have addressed Westminster hall are the Queen, Nelson Mandela, Pope Benedict, Obama and Aung San Suu Kyi. It's considered a great honour and isn't offered lightly. I don't think many people would say Trump belongs on that list. If the speaker says he's not inviting him then it's not happening.
He could still possibly be invited to address a different venue in parliament but it's unlikely with the way things are going at the moment.

WRITING.TITLE: Speaker Standing Up To Trump Is "A Thing Of Absolute Beauty"

WRITING.TEXT:
unfortunately being an Oxbridge graduate doesn't guarantee intellectual honesty. A disturbing number of our MP's are climate deniers too:
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/sep/10/climate-scepticism-still-rife-among-tory-mps-poll
My favourite troll in the house of commons at the moment is a guy called Jacob Rees Mogg, a relic from an aristocratic dynasty of coal mine owners who used to run one of our biggest newspapers. Here he is advocating for slashing our environmental standards to Indian levels now that were no longer held back by troublesome EU regulations:
http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-safety-standards-workers-rights-jacob-rees-mogg-a7459336.html

WRITING.TITLE: Is smearing a common problem with electric water distillers?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm trying to make an eau de vie style spirit by distilling a batch of home made cider through an electric water distiller. I've distilled it twice now, throwing away 100ml of foreshots on a 1 gallon wash and it still has an incredibly strong, biting acetone odour. So strong it makes you wince when you smell it. Is this because the still is running too hot and the foreshots are getting mixed in with the rest of the vapours?

I just looked it up, there is a trademark for it under several classes. Do you happen to know what class video games or books would fall under. I see under class 16 it says, "printed matter" - does that mean books? And would games fall under, "computer software"?

Anyone got any idea what might be going wrong?

WRITING.TITLE: Resources for design focussed individuals to learn Python?
WRITING.TEXT: I often hear about the benefits of learning how to write python scripts for automating tasks in 3D modelling packages like 3DS Max and Rhino. Could anyone recommend tutorials or guides geared towards this application of Python?

I'm looking for a more intuitive way to create custom textures for my game assets. MARI looks like a promising option, is it something that is commonly used in the game industry? Their website seems mostly focused on film which leads me to think the uv maps it outputs are probably going to be really resource intensive.

this is what I expected, I heard that Pillars was made in Unity so I should be able to get to grips with this fairly quickly.
I hadn't thought of deleting the unseen polygons, that would be a good idea but could it not potentially create problems with players getting stuck in models if there aren't any polygons to create colliders with?

I'm looking to expand my 3D asset creation portfolio beyond standard 3D views. How does asset creation for top down style RPG's a la Fallout 1/2 and Pillars of Eternity work? Is it any different from asset creation for standard 3D games? Could someone point me towards any resources for optimising models for this kind of game?
Todd Solondz (Happiness, Palindromes, Life During Wartime, Dark Horse)

I think I'd be edging more towards level design as I'm more comfortable with modelling structures and terrain than characters etc. I'll have a look on YouTube to see the kind of thing people are after. One last question - do you know roughly what the average salary would be for an entry level gig in this area?

WRITING.TITLE: UK Architects - Is there a limit to the amount of time you can take off between part 1 and 2?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm just about to graduate from my part 1 and want to take a few years off to do some other stuff. Is there a limit to the amount of time I can take off before doing my part 2 or could I theoretically take 10 years off and still come back to pick it up again. Is there a cutoff point where you eventually become disqualified?

Hey, thanks for the advice. Are 360 turntables what employers generally like to see then? Would it be a bonus to maybe stick in a bit of footage from some of the levels I've designed in Unreal Engine as well?

I'm in the UK, just about to finish my BA in Architecture. Throughout the course I've always found the 3D modelling aspect of my studies more engaging than the specifically architectural side. I was just wondering what scope there would be to move into the industry as an entry level environment designer/3D modeler after I graduate. I have extensive experience in several 3D modeling applications (Rhino, 3DS Max, Sketchup) and the Adobe suite (Photoshop, Illustrator, Indesign) as well as informal experience in Unreal engine from playing around with it in my spare time. Do you think game studio's would be open to an Architecture graduate if I put together a portfolio to demonstrate more game specific skills?

WRITING.TITLE: [Music] [IIL] Morphine, Twinemen, A.K.A.C.O.D [WEWIL]?
Mechanism for architecture project
WRITING.TEXT: I'm trying to make a reconfigurable system for an architecture project I'm working on. I want to make a pavilion with a ceiling that has a matrix of evenly spaced holes into which will be placed posts that can be easily pushed and pulled towards and away from the ground. I want to find a sliding mechanism whereby the posts would retain the position to where the user pulls them so that they can be at any height and don't simply fall all the way to the ground when pulled. Could someone point me to a diagram of a mechanism that has a function like this?

WRITING.TITLE: Advice for architecture project
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi everyone, I just bought and worked my way through the Arduino starter kit and would like to work it into a project I'm working on at university. Still a bit of a newbie so was hoping I could get some opinions on the best way to go about what I want to do.
Our theme for the year is architecture and politics so to kick it off I want to make a map of the council wards of Brighton out of translucent acrylic, lit from the back with RBG LED's. I want to make it so that when you flick a switch the LED's change colour to represent the controlling political party of the different areas from the 2010 to the 2015 election results.
Here's an image of the colour changes I'm aiming to achieve:
http://imgur.com/gallery/4N2THz3/new
And would these lights be a good choice for this project:
https://shop.pimoroni.com/products/adafruit-neopixel-mini-pcb-pack-of-5

I think the reference holds up actually. Aping a style that has passed usually doesn't work, it just ends up feeling very artificial. Case in point, the newly built town of Poundbury here in England.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jG_xsFARAVg
Prince Charles holds very similar views to what you're describing and his 30+ year vanity project has been building this weird little town that is desperately trying to go back to some ideal that the Prince holds in his mind of a Better Time. The problem is it just doesn't work, the time has passed and as you can see in the video it just hasn't been very popular and not many people live there. I visited the place recently and it just feels like a weird theme park. It looks like the buildings are made of stone but its mostly just concrete with a thin tiled veneer on top. Incorporating old styles into a modern aesthetic? I have no problem with that, but just copying doesn't work imo.
I'm particularly interested in the fertile crescent but any other region would be good too

WRITING.TEXT:
Thanks for your response,
Having had a look at the application procedure I do have a few more questions. I see you have to apply right off the bat with a topic and hypothesis for your thesis. Is this completely nailed down or is it a more fluid arrangement, evolving as you do further research? On a related note, do you have to select a particular location to focus on from the get go or does this also evolve with your work?
I've drummed up some ideas after looking at the criteria for acceptable thesis proposals that I wouldn't mind firing off an ex-student. Could you give me your opinion on a couple if I dm you the broad strokes? Also maybe some advice on the kind of sample work they're looking for from your portfolio?

WRITING.TITLE: Is anyone here studying for the RIBA Part 2 at Cambridge?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm interested in applying as I hear its more focused on written work than most Part 2 courses. However, I would be interested in hearing current/former students opinions how well rounded they feel the course is. How well do you feel it prepared you for the working world? Although I really enjoy writing, my main hesitation is that with the commitment to write four 5,000 word essays and a 15,000 word thesis that there would be less time to develop the practical skills necessary in working life after I graduate. Do the other aspects of the course successfully balance it out?

WRITING.TITLE: Good (preferably free) online resources for learning Grasshopper from scratch?
WRITING.TEXT: I just did a search on here and the only posts I could find were a little out of date. Can anyone recommend some stuff that's a little more recent?

WRITING.TITLE: Has anyone here done the RIBA Part 2 at Cambridge?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm interested in applying as I hear its heavily writing based, which I enjoy and is my strong suit, but would be interested in hearing former students opinions how well rounded the course is. How well did you feel it prepared you for the working world? My main hesitation is that with the greatly above average commitment to write four 5,000 word essays and a 15,000 word thesis that there would be less time to build the practical skills necessary in working life after I graduate. Do the other aspects of the course balance it out?
